greeting: Greetings from The On-Line Encyclopedia of Integer Sequences! http://oeis.org/

results.name: List of primitive prime divisors of the numbers (3^n-1)/2 (A003462) in their order of occurrence.
comment: Read A003462 term-by-term, factorize each term, write down any primes not seen before.
Except for n=2, there is at least one primitive prime divisor for every n. [From _T. D. Noe_, Mar 01 2010]
link: T. D. Noe, Primes for n up to 500 (using the Cunningham tables)
G. Everest et al., Primes generated by recurrence sequences, Amer. Math. Monthly, 114 (No. 5, 2007), 417-431.
K. Zsigmondy, Zur Theorie der Potenzreste, Monatsh. Math., 3 (1892), 265-284.
maple: for i from 1 to nops(s) do if isprime(s[i]) then
# get primitive prime divisors in order
for i from 1 to nops(s) do t3:=ifactors(s[i])[2];
for j from 1 to nops(t3) do p := t3[j][1]; new:=1;
for k from 1 to np do if p = t2[k] then new:= -1; break; fi; od;
if new = 1 then np:=np+1; t2:=[op(t2),p]; fi; od; od;
xref: Cf. A003462, A076481, A028491. If 3 is replaced by 2 we get A000225, A004668, A000043, A108974 respectively.
results.author: _N. J. A. Sloane_, May 13 2007
